items.title: Gary Paffett è il nuovo Direttore Sportivo di Cupra Kiro
items.description: Cupra Kiro annuncia la nomina di Gary Paffett al ruolo di Direttore Sportivo in vista dell'inizio della stagione 2025/26 del Campionato Mondiale FIA F
items.body:
Gary Paffett è il nuovo Direttore Sportivo di Cupra Kiro
15 Agosto 2025
 Formula E, Motorsports
0

Cupra Kiro annuncia la nomina di Gary Paffett al ruolo di Direttore Sportivo in vista dell’inizio della stagione 2025/26 del Campionato Mondiale FIA Formula E, previsto per la fine dell’anno.
Con oltre 25 anni di esperienza nel mondo delle corse automobilistiche, Gary porta una prospettiva ricca e dinamica a Cupra Kiro, che è entrata in Formula E nella stagione 2024/25 e ha concluso la stagione con un primo podio, una pole position e una storica vittoria all’E-Prix di Giacarta.
Ex pilota professionista, Gary ha vinto il competitivo campionato DTM nel 2005 e nel 2018 ed è stato collaudatore per la McLaren in Formula 1 dal 2005 al 2014. Ha debuttato in Formula E con HWA Racelab nella stagione 2018/19.
Dopo essersi ritirato dalle competizioni nel 2019, Gary è entrato a far parte di Mercedes EQ come Consulente Sportivo e Tecnico. In seguito, è diventato Team Manager tra i due titoli consecutivi di Campione del Mondo Piloti e Team di Formula E, svolgendo un ruolo fondamentale in entrambi gli incarichi. Quando il team è passato a McLaren, ha mantenuto il ruolo, assumendo anche quello di Direttore Sportivo.
Riportando al Chief Operating Officer, Russell O’Hagan, Gary è il candidato ideale per rafforzare ulteriormente le attività di Cupra Kiro in vista dell’arrivo della quarta generazione di Formula E, prevista per la fine del 2026.
La sua nomina segna la prima di una serie di aggiunte pianificate al team dirigenziale di Cupra Kiro, mentre l’organizzazione continua a crescere un successo duraturo in Formula E.
Fonte: Kiro Race Co

items.title: Anche a Siena abusivi della ricarica. E la Polizia Locale…
items.description:
Anche a Siena abusivi della ricarica in azione, parcheggiando l’auto davanti alle colonnine. E la Polizia Locale, segnala…
L'articolo Anch
items.body:
Anche a Siena abusivi della ricarica in azione, parcheggiando l’auto davanti alle colonnine. E la Polizia Locale, segnala Stefano, non interviene. Vaielettrico risponde. Per scriverci: info@vaielettrico.it

“Vi racconto la mia esperienza di ieri sera. Sono in vacanza nelle campagne senesi e decido di andare a cena nel centro di Siena. Individuo due gruppi di colonnine a ridosso della ZTL (il primo a porta San Marco ed il secondo in via Mascagni). Arrivo e trovo tutti gli stalli occupati da auto termiche. Ero a zero di batteria, ma fortunatamente ho un’auto ibrida plug in. Avevo però programmato di caricarla lì visto che dove alloggio non è possibile. Ma questo è il meno (anche se non dovrebbe). In quel momento passa un’auto della Polizia Municipale, la fermo e spiego il problema. La risposta è epica: “Deve chiamare la Centrale e mandano una pattuglia”. Rispondo basito chiedendo che faccia qualcosa quella pattuglia, ma mi rispondono di no, che devo chiamare. Chiedo quindi che lo facciano loro, ma se ne fregano altamente e se ne vanno. Chiaramente non ho chiamato nessuno, perché nessuno si sarebbe mai presentato visti i toni. Ho parcheggiato a pagamento e tornato indietro a benzina. Grazie dell’attenzione“. Stefano Boffa

Risposta. Bisognerebbe sapere per quale motivo la pattuglia in questione si è rifiutata di intervenire. Forse un intervento urgente da effettuare altrove? Oppure, come sostiene Stefano, non avevano nessuna voglia di multare le auto in sosta davanti alle colonnine, come invece prescrive il Codice della Strada? Quel che sappiamo per certo, dalle tante segnalazioni dai lettori, è che il malcostume di parcheggiare nelle ricariche d’estate aumenta in maniera esponenziale. Con una diffusa impunità, dato che quasi mai questi comportamenti scorretti vengono sanzionati.

items.body: Cultura & Società Nuova truffa del POS, adesso rimani davvero in mutande: solo così non ti svuotano il conto    Clarissa Missarelli    Agosto 16, 2025     Truffa: come difendersi - Greenstyle.it La crescente diffusione delle tecnologie di pagamento elettronico, come il POS, ha anche aperto la porta a nuove truffe che stanno mettendo in allarme i consumatori italiani.Negli ultimi mesi, infatti, si è registrato un aumento preoccupante di episodi di frodi legate all’uso di dispositivi POS contraffatti o manomessi, con conseguenze finanziarie pesanti per chi ne è vittima.La truffa del POS: come funziona e perché spaventa gli italianiIl meccanismo fraudolento alla base di questa truffa prevede l’utilizzo di terminali POS alterati, ovvero apparecchi in cui i malintenzionati hanno inserito dispositivi in grado di clonare i dati delle carte di credito o debito durante la transazione. Una volta raccolte queste informazioni, i truffatori possono effettuare prelievi o acquisti online senza autorizzazione, svuotando il conto corrente della vittima in modo rapido e quasi impercettibile. Truffa del POS -Greenstyle.itLe vittime spesso non si accorgono immediatamente della truffa, poiché le operazioni fraudolente vengono effettuate a distanza di giorni o settimane e possono essere mascherate da transazioni apparentemente legittime. Questo tipo di frode ha colpito particolarmente i piccoli esercizi commerciali e i clienti meno esperti, che tendono a fidarsi ciecamente dei terminali POS presenti nei negozi.Recenti dati aggiornati al 2025 indicano che l’Italia è tra i paesi europei con il maggior numero di segnalazioni legate a frodi di questo tipo, con un incremento del 25% rispetto all’anno precedente. Le autorità stanno intensificando i controlli, ma è fondamentale anche che i consumatori adottino strategie efficaci per tutelarsi.Per evitare di diventare vittima della truffa del POS, è essenziale adottare alcune precauzioni durante l’utilizzo della carta di pagamento:Controllare sempre che il terminale POS non presenti anomalie evidenti, come parti aggiunte o fili scoperti. In caso di dubbi, è preferibile rifiutare la transazione e rivolgersi a un altro esercizio commerciale.Verificare regolarmente l’estratto conto bancario, così da individuare tempestivamente eventuali addebiti sospetti e segnalarli immediatamente alla propria banca.Prediligere l’uso di carte con sistemi di sicurezza avanzati, come la tecnologia contactless con limite basato su importi ridotti, oppure carte dotate di codice dinamico che cambia a ogni transazione.Installare app di mobile banking che permettono notifiche in tempo reale per ogni operazione effettuata, facilitando il monitoraggio continuo del proprio conto.Diffidare da richieste di digitazione del PIN in presenza di terzi e non fornire mai dati sensibili a sconosciuti o attraverso canali non ufficiali.Gli esperti consigliano inoltre di preferire metodi di pagamento alternativi quando possibile, come le app di pagamento digitale che utilizzano sistemi di autenticazione biometrica, garantendo un ulteriore livello di protezione contro accessi non autorizzati.In risposta all’emergenza truffe legate ai POS, le autorità italiane hanno rafforzato le normative riguardanti la sicurezza dei pagamenti elettronici, imponendo standard più stringenti ai produttori di terminali e agli istituti di credito. Sono stati avviati programmi di sensibilizzazione rivolti sia ai commercianti che ai consumatori, al fine di diffondere la conoscenza delle tecniche di frode più comuni e di come prevenirle.Parallelamente, la ricerca tecnologica ha sviluppato sistemi di monitoraggio e intelligenza artificiale capaci di rilevare comportamenti anomali nelle transazioni, bloccando in tempo reale quelle sospette. Anche le banche stanno aggiornando i propri protocolli di sicurezza, offrendo ai clienti servizi come la possibilità di bloccare temporaneamente la carta tramite app o di impostare limiti di spesa personalizzati.La consapevolezza e la prudenza rimangono però le armi più efficaci per difendersi da questa nuova minaccia, soprattutto perché le truffe legate al POS si evolvono rapidamente, adattandosi a nuove tecnologie e strategie criminali. In un contesto in cui il denaro digitale diventa sempre più prevalente, conoscere le modalità di attacco e adottare comportamenti responsabili rappresenta l’unico modo per proteggere il proprio patrimonio. items.title: Trappole fiscali nei bonus edilizi, le insidie da conosce: quanto rischi se ti affidi agli esperti sbagliati
items.description:
La Corte di Cassazione torna a pronunciarsi su un tema di grande rilievo per migliaia di contribuenti italiani.
L'articolo Trappole fiscali nei bonus
items.body: Economia Trappole fiscali nei bonus edilizi, le insidie da conosce: quanto rischi se ti affidi agli esperti sbagliati    Christian Camberini    Agosto 16, 2025     Come richiedere gli incentivi e dove rivolgersi(www.greenstyle.it) La Corte di Cassazione torna a pronunciarsi su un tema di grande rilievo per migliaia di contribuenti italiani.La Corte di Cassazione torna a pronunciarsi su un tema di grande rilievo per migliaia di contribuenti italiani: la responsabilità fiscale legata all’uso dei bonus edilizi, con particolare attenzione al Superbonus 110%. La recente ordinanza n. 13358, depositata il 20 maggio 2025, chiarisce in modo definitivo i rischi a cui va incontro chi si affida a professionisti per gestire queste agevolazioni senza mantenere un controllo attento sull’operato degli incaricati.Bonus edilizi e responsabilità del contribuente: un quadro complessoNegli ultimi anni, l’introduzione e la rapida diffusione del Superbonus e degli altri incentivi fiscali per lavori di ristrutturazione hanno spinto molti proprietari a rivolgersi a consulenti fiscali, tecnici o general contractor per gestire la complessa procedura di accesso ai vantaggi fiscali. Il meccanismo di cessione del credito e di compensazione tramite modello F24 ha semplificato l’uso degli incentivi, ma ha anche aperto la strada a numerose irregolarità e frodi che hanno poi innescato un’ondata di verifiche fiscali e contenziosi.È proprio in questo contesto che si inserisce la pronuncia della Cassazione, che evidenzia come la semplice delega della gestione fiscale non sia sufficiente a esonerare il contribuente da responsabilità penali e tributarie. La sentenza sottolinea la necessità di un controllo attivo e costante da parte di chi beneficia delle agevolazioni. Fate attenzione a questi bonus (www.greenstyle.it)La vicenda alla base dell’ordinanza riguarda un titolare di una ditta individuale destinatario di un avviso di accertamento per indebita compensazione IVA, derivante da fatture inesistenti per oltre 670.000 euro. L’imprenditore aveva affidato la contabilità a professionisti esterni, sostenendo di non essere a conoscenza delle irregolarità e di essere stato vittima della manipolazione delle fatture da parte dei consulenti incaricati.Nonostante l’assoluzione in sede penale con formula piena – il fatto non sussiste – a livello tributario la responsabilità è stata confermata, poiché il contribuente non aveva esercitato un’efficace vigilanza sull’operato dei professionisti. La Cassazione ha quindi ribadito un principio già consolidato: chi affida la gestione fiscale a terzi non si libera automaticamente dalle conseguenze degli illeciti commessi da questi ultimi.La Corte ha evidenziato come la responsabilità del contribuente persista, a meno che non dimostri di aver adottato un comportamento attivo e diligente nella supervisione degli incaricati. Non basta, quindi, limitarsi a una fiducia passiva o a un mero affidamento formale.Un aspetto importante della sentenza riguarda la possibilità di escludere la responsabilità fiscale per chi dimostra di aver esercitato una vigilanza concreta e documentabile sull’operato dei professionisti. La Cassazione riconosce che il contribuente può essere esonerato se prova di aver:adottato misure idonee a monitorare la correttezza delle attività delegate;mantenuto un controllo costante nel tempo;segnalato tempestivamente eventuali irregolarità con comunicazioni formali o denunce.Questo modello di responsabilità, definito come “colpa vigilata”, rappresenta una vera e propria via di tutela per chi si impegna a supervisionare in modo attivo e non superficiale la gestione delle pratiche legate ai bonus edilizi. items.title: The future intensification of hydrological extremes and whiplashes in the contiguous United States increase community vulnerability
items.body:
Download PDF

Article
    
        
            Open access

Published: 16 August 2025

The future intensification of hydrological extremes and whiplashes in the contiguous United States increase community vulnerability
                    Surendra Maharjan1,2, Wenzhao Li1,2, John D. Bolten3 & …Hesham El-Askary 
            ORCID: orcid.org/0000-0002-9876-37051,2,4 Show authors

Communications Earth & Environment

volume 6, Article number: 668 (2025)
            Cite this article

Subjects
        
            Climate-change mitigationWater resources

AbstractHydroclimatic whiplash rapid shifts between drought and flood poses growing risks to U.S. communities. Here, we assess historical extremes and future projections using a normalized streamflow metric: the annual mean flow’s deviation from the 1981–2020 average, expressed as a fraction of that average. This metric is applied to United States Geological Survey records and Localized Constructed Analogs downscaled projections under Representative Concentration Pathways 4.5 and 8.5. Results reveal sharp regional disparities, with drought deficits exceeding 300% of normal flow during multi-year droughts. By linking hydrologic outcomes with the Federal Emergency Management Agency’s National Risk Index, we find that counties facing the deepest droughts also experience the highest annual losses and lowest resilience. Under the high-emissions scenario, sustained surpluses emerge only in already resilient regions. These findings highlight the urgent need for region-specific, adaptive water management to protect vulnerable populations from worsening climate extremes.

IntroductionHydrological whiplash, defined by rapid shifts between hydrological extremes, such as floods and droughts, is increasingly recognized as a complex and urgent compound hazard globally1. These sudden transitions result from interactions between temperature, precipitation, and shifting atmospheric circulation patterns, which create pressing challenges for water resource management across the contiguous United States (CONUS)2,3. These patterns are influenced by anthropogenic factors, such as land use changes, water withdrawals, reservoir operations, and irrigation practices4,5, alongside the accelerating rise in global temperatures6,7.Recent trends across CONUS highlight the severity of hydrological whiplash events. California experienced a prolonged drought from 2012 to 2016, resulting in widespread agricultural and economic losses8, followed by devastating floods during the winter of 2016–2017 that caused extensive infrastructure damage3. Similarly, Texas endured an exceptional drought from 2011 to 2015, causing substantial water scarcity and agricultural losses9, only to experience record-breaking floods in 2015 that further strained resources. The Mississippi River Basin provides another stark example, where an extreme drought in 2012 was followed by unprecedented flooding in 2013, impacting agriculture and transportation systems in the region10,11. These examples underscore the pressing need for an extensive comprehension of hydroclimatic whiplashes, as the combined economic burden of droughts and floods across CONUS continues to escalate into billions of dollars.These observed trends are increasingly driven by climate variability, which is intensifying the intensity and frequency of these extreme hydroclimatic events, obscuring water management efforts across the CONUS12,13. As the planet warms, the Odds of experiencing abrupt shifts between flood and drought increase, further stressing water resources and infrastructure3,14,15. Numerous studies have documented projected increases in the frequency and intensity of extreme precipitation events across most regions of the globe16,17,18,19,20. Grasping the relationships between meteorological droughts and following hydrological extremes is crucial for early warning systems and effective water management strategies21. Indices such as the Palmer Drought Severity Index (PDSI)22 and the Standardized Precipitation Evapotranspiration Index (SPEI)23 are widely used to detect meteorological droughts based on atmospheric water balance. The Rapid Change Index (RCI)24 helps monitor abrupt shifts between opposing hydrological states, such as drought to flood transitions, while the Compound Event Index (CEI)25 provides a multivariate framework for evaluating co-occurring extremes and short-timescale hazard clustering. Despite these advancements, existing tools cannot fully capture the complexities of hydroclimatic whiplashes and their socio-economic consequences24,26. This demands a comprehensive study that incorporates both hydrological floods and droughts, using water supply metrics such as deficit and surplus25. Such an approach should address the limitations of current methods to provide a more holistic assessment of hydroclimatic extremes across CONUS, offering critical insights for water management, disaster preparedness27,28, and strategies to support the vulnerable communities most at risk3,29. Therefore, this study aims to examine hydroclimatic variability, linking climate change to specific regional impacts and vulnerabilities. This approach will not only enable a more accurate evaluation of extreme historical and future conditions but also emphasize the escalating frequency and magnitude of hydroclimatic whiplashes under evolving climate scenarios.Compared to widely used hydroclimatic indices such as PDSI30, SPEI23, RCI24, and CEI25, our approach offers several theoretical and operational advantages. Theoretically, PDSI and SPEI track meteorological or soil moisture droughts based on atmospheric inputs, but they do not capture surface water availability or cumulative hydrological response over the full water year. RCI and CEI identify rapid transitions or compound extremes, but they are event-based and do not provide continuous, basin-scale classification of annual hydrological regimes. Region-specific tools also exist: the Sacramento Valley Index (SVI) aggregates unimpaired flows from key gauges to classify water-year types in northern California, while the Basin Water Availability index derived from the San Joaquin Area Simulation Model (SANJASM) performs a similar role for the agriculturally intensive San Joaquin Valley31. Because they depend on basin-specific, reconstructed unimpaired flows, these indices are hard to transfer elsewhere. In contrast, our normalized hydrological indicator is built on streamflow anomalies32, providing a direct, basin-sensitive measure of water year status across time and space. Practically, it supports water supply planning by capturing both surplus and deficit dynamics, and from a real-world perspective, it serves as an early-warning and classification tool for water managers, agricultural planners, and resilience agencies, particularly under shifting climate regimes.To demonstrate its utility, we first apply our indicator to the long-term United States Geological Survey (USGS) discharge archive across CONUS, objectively classifying every water year at each gauge as Critically Dry, Dry, Above Normal, Below Normal, or Wet. We then propagate the same framework forward in time using Coupled Model Intercomparison Project Phase 5 (CMIP5) climate projections (Representative Concentration Pathways (RCP) 4.5 and RCP 8.5), quantifying trends, transition frequencies, and emerging hotspots of hydro-extremes. What makes this approach innovative is its ability to integrate drought- and flood-characterization within one transferable metric and to flag hydrological whiplash flips rapid wet–dry or dry–wet transitions that conventional single-hazard indices miss. Finally, by overlaying these climate-driven shifts with county-scale socioeconomic exposure and community-resilience layers, we create an integrated framework that links basin-level hydrology to human vulnerability, yielding actionable intelligence for adaptive water-resource planning in an era of escalating hydro-climatic volatility.ResultsHistorical hydrological whiplashes in CONUSThe analysis of the water year index of hydrological conditions across Hydrologic Unit Code (HUC) 2-level basins from 2018 to 2023 reveals pronounced regional variability and increasing occurrences of extreme transitions between dry and wet conditions across CONUS. In 2018 (Fig. 1), the western United States (U.S.), including the Pacific Northwest, California Basin, and parts of the Southwest, experienced pronounced dry anomalies, while wetter conditions dominated the Midwest and Eastern Seaboard, indicating a clear regional contrast. By 2019 (Fig. 1), wetter-than-normal conditions spread extensively across the central and eastern basins, particularly in the Mississippi River Basin, Ohio River Basin, and Southeast regions, while localized dry patches remained persistent in parts of the western U.S. In 2020 (Fig. 1), a stark shift occurred as dry conditions intensified across half of west of U.S., particularly in California Basin, Great Basin, and the upper reaches of the Colorado River Basin, while the eastern regions maintained near-normal to wetter conditions. Moving into 2021 (Fig. 1), extremely dry conditions expanded across the western and central U.S., particularly in the Southwest and northern Great Plains, while wetter anomalies were observed in parts of the Northeast and Southeast. The year 2022 (Fig. 1) was characterized by further intensification of dry conditions in central and southern regions, including the Missouri River Basin, Texas, and parts of the Midwest, while wetter-than-normal conditions re-emerged in parts of the eastern U.S., particularly in the Northeast. In 2023 (Fig. 1), widespread wet conditions were observed across the Mississippi River Basin, the Ohio River Basin, and portions of the Great Plains, contrasting sharply with persistent dry anomalies in the Southwest and the Western Great Basin.Fig. 1: Shifts in water year conditions and normalized streamflow deficit/surplus at United States Geological Survey (USGS) hydrological stations across the United States, 2018 to 2023.The normalized indicator (range −1 to 1) expresses deficit (negative) or surplus (positive) relative to the 1981–2020 mean annual stream‑flow volume. Circle color denotes the categorical water‑year class: wet (W, dark blue), above‑normal (AN, light blue), below‑normal (BN, yellow), dry (D, orange) and critically dry (C, red), while circle area is proportional to the magnitude of the indicator, so larger symbols mark more extreme conditions.Full size imageFig. S1 further illustrates the time-dependent Switches and distribution of water year types across 18 Unique HUC regions in the U.S. from 1981 to 2023. The percent Occurrence of Critical, Wet, and other water year types emphasizes Substantial annual-scale variability observed across all regions. While trends were analyzed for all three categories, results from the modified Mann–Kendall test (including both tau and p values) showed no discernible trends in water year types for most HUC regions, except for HUC 13, as detailed in Table S1. Fig. S2 highlights the switches between water year types, revealing occasional peaks in shifts from Critical to Wet (C to W) and Wet to Critical (W to C). For example, HUC 4 and HUC 5 exhibited substantial switching events in 1995. However, despite these isolated years, there is no apparent decreasing or increasing trend in the frequency of shifts across the analyzed regions. The Modified Mann–Kendall test further confirmed that transitions between wet and dry conditions are not statistically significant across all HUC levels, as summarized in Table S2–S3.Over this 6-year period, a clear pattern of hydrological whiplash marked by abrupt transitions between wet and dry extremes is evident, particularly in the western and central U.S. These observations underscore the pronounced interannual variability across the CONUS and emphasize the challenges in predicting and managing such extremes. While some regions exhibit significant switching events, the absence of long-term trends in water year-type transitions highlights the complex and localized nature of hydroclimatic variability. These findings reinforce the need for improved monitoring tools and adaptive water management strategies to mitigate the impacts of extreme hydrological shifts on water resources, infrastructure, and ecosystems under a changing climate.The historical analysis provides a critical foundation for understanding observed trends in extreme hydrological conditions, including the increased frequency of droughts and floods across many regions in recent decades. This historical variability, marked by notable transitions from prolonged dry periods to sudden wet extremes, highlights the dynamic and unpredictable nature of past hydroclimatic shifts. For instance, as documented in the California Basin and Mississippi River Basin, periods such as the early 1990s and post-2015 exhibited rapid whiplashes between drought and flood conditions, underscoring the increasing severity of hydrological variability in the observed record.Escalation of hydrological extremes in future water yearsLooking ahead, streamflow projections based on General Circulation Model (GCM) inputs reveal a complex and evolving hydrological future for U.S. basins, categorized by HUC2 similarities (Fig. S3). Under changing climate scenarios, notable shifts in water year type distributions are evident, reflecting the diverse regional responses to projected climate impacts. Figure 2 illustrates the most frequent (mode) water year type across multiple models under RCP 4.5 and RCP 8.5 based on the second generation Canadian Earth System Model (CanESM2), chosen to capture extreme events better.Fig. 2: Latitudinal evolution of water‑year type across four western U.S. regions under medium‑ and high‑emissions scenarios.Left‑hand panels outline the West Coast, Colorado River, South‑Central and North‑Central domains (red hatching shows the regions used). Center and right panels are Hovmöller diagrams (latitude on the y‑axis, calendar year 1950–2100 on the x‑axis) generated from the CanESM2 model, for RCP 4.5 (center) and RCP 8.5 (right). The color represents water‑year class category: wet (W, dark blue), above‑normal (AN, light blue), below‑normal (BN, yellow), dry (D, orange) or critically dry (C, red). Persistent warm colors mark an increasing prevalence of dry and critically dry years, whereas cool hues indicate wetter years and potential extreme floods.Full size imageThe results show distinct regional trends. Wet years become increasingly dominant after the 2060s in regions like the West Coast and North Central, primarily due to the mode’s sensitivity to wet conditions, which are weighed at 30%. In contrast, regions like the Colorado River Basin and South-Central exhibit a persistent dominance of critical (drought) years after the 2060s, particularly under RCP 8.5, signaling heightened vulnerability to prolonged dry periods. These projections underscore the divergent hydrological futures for U.S. basins, with some regions trending wetter while others face increasingly severe and persistent dry conditions.Complementing these findings, Figs. S4–S6 in conjunction with Fig. 2, reveals considerable inter-model variability in projected climate patterns. Different models exhibit varying magnitudes and spatial patterns of temperature, precipitation, and hydrological extremes, reflecting the inherent complexity and uncertainty of climate projections. While the CanESM2 model provides an average representation of expected trends, additional Hovmöller plots from models like Center National de Recherches Météorologiques Coupled Global Climate Model, version 5 (CNRM-CM5) (Cool/Wet), Hadley Center Global Environment Model version 2—Earth System (HadGEM2-ES) (Warm/Dry), and Model for Interdisciplinary Research on Climate, version 5 (MIROC5) (Complementary) offer a broader perspective of regional variability under RCP 4.5 and RCP 8.5 scenarios. Future projections indicate an amplification of historical patterns, with extended multi-year droughts and prolonged wet periods emerging as dominant features. For example, HadGEM2-ES model (2060–2080, Fig. S5), MIROC5 model (2070–2090, Fig. S6), and CanESM2 (2055–2060 and 2080–2090, Fig. 2) highlight persistent droughts followed by intense wet conditions. These findings suggest a continuation and intensification of past variability, with rapid transitions between flood and drought conditions increasing the likelihood of hydrological whiplash events in the future.The implications of these results are profound: the amplification of historical extremes into more severe and frequent hydrological events could cause pronounced disruptions to water availability, agricultural productivity, and infrastructure resilience. Rapid transitions between prolonged drought and intense wet periods pose major challenges for water resource management, ecosystem stability, and community adaptation strategies. Understanding how these patterns evolve from observed historical trends to projected extremes is essential for developing robust adaptation and mitigation plans to address the growing unpredictability and intensity of hydrological extremes in a warming climate.To further illustrate the emerging patterns, Fig. 3 contrasts the historical baseline (1981–2020) with two future windows 2021–2060 and 2061–2099 under RCP 4.5 and RCP 8.5 across four U.S. basin groups, defined by regional similarities at the HUC‑2 level (West Coast, Colorado River, South‑Central, and North‑Central). In every group, the percentage of other water‑year classes (Above‑Normal, Below Normal, and Dry; panels c, f, i, l) shrinks while extremes intensify. Critical years (panels a, d, g, j) rise most steeply in the South‑Central basins, climbing from about 15% to roughly 26% by the late century; all scenarios except the West Coast near‑future case show significant increases. Wet years (panels b, e, h, k) surge most in the North‑Central basins, jumping from roughly 30% historically to nearly 49% in the near‑future RCP 8.5 scenario and about 40% in the far‑future RCP 4.5 case. Correspondingly, the proportion of other years falls to 41–45% in the North‑Central group and declines markedly in the Colorado River and South‑Central basins as well. Collectively, these shifts point to a future in which extreme (Critical or Wet) water‑year conditions dominate, and near‑normal years become increasingly scarce across all four HUC‑2 regions.Fig. 3: Evolving streamflow patterns in U.S. basins across historical records and future projections.Columns compare the percentage of a Critical, b Wet, and c all other water‑year classes (Above‑Normal + Below‑Normal + Dry) across four future windows: 2021–2060 under RCP 4.5 and RCP 8.5 (NF‑4.5, NF‑8.5) and 2061–2099 under RCP 4.5 and RCP 8.5 (FF‑4.5, FF‑8.5). Rows correspond to four basin groups: West Coast (a–c), Colorado River (d–f), South‑Central (g–i), and North‑Central (j–l). Significance symbols above each future boxplot indicate departure from the historical baseline (1981–2020): ns (not significant) (p > 0.05), *(p ≤ 0.05), **(p ≤ 0.01), ***(p ≤ 0.001), and ****(p ≤ 0.0001). Black dashed lines mark historical reference levels of 15% Critical, 30% Wet, and 55% Other conditions. Box plots show the interquartile range (IQR) (box), the median (horizontal line in box), 1.5× IQR (whiskers), and maximum/minimum (horizontal lines outside box).Full size imageImpact of extended droughts and flooding on communitiesBuilding on these findings, we examine how hydrological extremes severe multi-year droughts and cumulative wet conditions affect different communities, emphasizing the interplay between hydrological variability and community-specific characteristics. Identifying the most vulnerable populations and regions is critical for understanding disparities in exposure, vulnerability, and resilience across diverse socioeconomic and geographic contexts. By analyzing these factors, we can better assess how hydrological extremes shape the adaptive capacity and long-term sustainability of impacted communities. These insights underscore the urgent need for effective strategies to mitigate the impacts of droughts and surpluses, ensuring that interventions address the unique challenges faced by communities, especially those most at risk.Figures 4a, b quantify the maximum cumulative deficits during severe multi-year droughts, revealing significant regional fluctuation in water scarcities under both moderate (RCP 4.5) and extreme warming (RCP 8.5) scenarios, while also highlighting their critical connections to socioeconomic factors and associated vulnerabilities. Under RCP 8.5, regions such as the Colorado River Basin, West Coast, and South-Central exhibit extreme deficits, with some stations recording deficits surpassing three times the annual water volume. These extreme deficits underscore the heightened potential for future extreme droughts, posing severe risks to water resources and regional stability. The integration of socioeconomic indices reveals substantial disparities in drought impacts across regions with differing economic and social characteristics. Developing equitable and region-specific strategies will be critical to minimizing the adverse effects of these hydrological extremes on vulnerable populations.DiscussionIn this study, we introduce a tailored Hydrological Water Year Index based on USGS data. This index supports water management by enabling early forecasts of water year conditions, facilitating strategic planning and resource allotment to address anticipated extremes. The research highlights changing hydrological trends across the U.S., characterized by increased streamflow fluctuation and more frequent whiplash events after 2015. Although no significant long-term trends were detected, the rise in transient variability aligns with climate model projections for the region35. This variability is exhibited by the sharp transition to wet conditions in 2019, after prolonged severe droughts36.Model projections suggest an increase in extreme dry and wet water years, coupled with a decline in non-extreme conditions across all basins. This shift to frequent and severe Wet and Critically Dry years, causing notable hurdles for hydrological management in the U.S., such changes challenge Conventional water management approaches reliant on historical record and assumptions of stationarity, emphasizing the need to account for both natural climate variability and the impacts of global warming37. The regional variation in susceptibility to hydrological whiplash across the continental U.S. is shaped by a complex interplay of climatic and geographic factors. The spatial distribution of drought and surplus conditions under RCP 4.5 and RCP 8.5 (Fig. 4a–d) reveals pronounced regional disparities in projected hydrological extremes across the western and central U.S. For instance, the Southwest and Southern Great Plains exhibit stronger and more widespread streamflow deficits, particularly under RCP 8.5. These deficits are especially evident in the Rio Grande, Colorado, and Arkansas River basins. This heightened vulnerability is closely linked to a combination of snowmelt dependency, elevated interannual precipitation variability, and limited groundwater reserves5. Warming-induced reductions in snowpack and earlier melt timing reduce seasonal water availability, while a reliance on monsoon- or El Niño and the Southern Oscillation—modulated precipitation contributes to interannual unpredictability. In addition, many basins in these regions experience chronic groundwater overdraft, making them less resilient to drought shocks38.In contrast, the Upper Mississippi, Missouri, and Ohio River basins show more frequent and spatially extensive positive streamflow anomalies (surpluses), particularly under RCP 8.5. These patterns align with projected increases in cold-season precipitation, snow-to-rain transitions, and runoff intensification due to more frequent heavy rainfall events39. The concentration of moisture inputs during winter and spring is expected to increase peak flows and flood risks in these regions, especially under high-emissions scenarios40. Unlike arid basins, these humid and semi-humid regions also benefit from more consistent soil moisture replenishment and deeper groundwater stores, increasing their runoff generation efficiency under enhanced precipitation regimes41,42.Our hydrological projections, based on Localized Constructed Analogs (LOCA) and Bias-Correction and Spatial Disaggregation (BCSD)-routed VIC streamflow data with CMIP5 GCM inputs, highlight challenges in integrating climate models into hydrological assessments43,44. Recent studies reveal that CMIP6 reduces uncertainty for temperature and precipitation compared to CMIP545 but still struggles with basin-level trends, especially in arid regions46, and simulating extremes in areas with complex topography47. For precipitation, while both CMIP5 and CMIP6 project an overall increase at the annual scale, CMIP6 projections tend to show greater intra-annual variability. For example, CMIP6 models often project increases in wet-season precipitation but reductions during dry months, resulting in a more uneven seasonal distribution of water availability compared to CMIP548. This seasonal divergence has critical implications for hydrological extremes, water storage, and allocation planning. Moreover, the presence of hot models in CMIP6, those with elevated Equilibrium Climate Sensitivity and Transient Climate Response, may lead to inflated hydrological extremes in some scenarios49,50,51, potentially skewing the interpretation of runoff risks in water-stressed regions. Given that our runoff indicator is derived from normalized streamflow anomalies, it is sensitive to changes in both the magnitude and timing of runoff. As such, CMIP6’s stronger seasonal contrasts and amplified warming could influence the frequency and severity of projected surplus or deficit conditions. Figs. S31–S48 compare CMIP5 and CMIP6 basin-scale precipitation projections by examining mean values and inter-annual coefficients of variation for every U.S. HUC. Apart from a few basins, Upper Mississippi (07), Texas-Gulf (11), and Lower Colorado (15), CMIP5 closely mirrors spatial gradients and variability patterns found in CMIP6, particularly across the eastern and central regions (HUCs 01–04, 06, 08–10). Although CMIP6 is the newer generation, recent studies highlight unresolved issues such as a subset of hot models with unrealistically high equilibrium climate sensitivity, persistent wet biases over the central U.S., and exaggerated springtime convective rainfall that can complicate hydrologic impact assessments and sometimes inflate projected changes. Given the broad CMIP5–CMIP6 agreement for most basins and the outstanding biases in parts of the CMIP6 ensemble, CMIP5 remains suitable for the present analysis. Future work should incorporate a broader suite of CMIP6-forced streamflow projections as they become available, expanding beyond the currently limited subset to better capture model-generation uncertainty and refine long-term water-resource assessments.While our findings reveal distinct spatial patterns of drought and flood extremes, it is important to interpret these outcomes through the lens of inherent uncertainty. This uncertainty arises from three primary sources: (1) model-structure uncertainty for instance, the CMIP ensemble contains hot (high-sensitivity) and cold (low-sensitivity) models whose contrasting representations of atmospheric and land-surface processes broaden the spread of projections52; (2) VIC model parameters, particularly within hydrological models, where multiple equally good solutions and non-uniqueness introduce ambiguity53; and (3) scenario uncertainty, as socioeconomic trajectories and emission levels vary widely between pathways like RCP 4.5 and RCP 8.554. Figs. S49–S52 illustrate the spatial distribution of modeling uncertainty in future flood and drought indicators across the CONUS for both RCP 4.5 and RCP 8.5 scenarios. Uncertainty, here, is measured by the standard deviation of ensemble projections55; model-structure and parameter uncertainties could not be quantified because the requisite VIC configuration and calibration information are unavailable. The maps reveal persistent hotspots of high scenario uncertainty in Colorado, Missouri, and Arkansas regions where complex terrain, transitional climates, and divergent model treatments of snowmelt, convection, and floodplain processes magnify differences among ensemble members. Because the uncertainty metric represents only ±1σ across the CMIP-forced ensemble and does not yet include VIC structural or parameter error, these hotspots should be viewed as lower-bound estimates of the true projection spread. Decision-makers in these states should therefore interpret model outputs with heightened caution, while also supporting targeted data collection and hydrologic-model refinement to narrow the uncertainty envelope in subsequent assessments12,56.Furthermore, variability in projected extremes, especially under high-emission scenarios, is amplified by differences in moisture transport, storm dynamics, and warming rates across models. While ensemble medians are used to reduce bias, they do not eliminate the spread among projections, which must be considered when informing adaptation strategies. However, in addition to climate variability, other factors such as land-use changes, unsustainable water management practices, urban expansion, and broader anthropogenic influences also contribute to the observed hydrological shifts. For example, deforestation in the Amazon Basin has been shown to increase runoff and disrupt streamflow seasonality due to reduced evapotranspiration and canopy interception57. Similarly, intensive irrigation withdrawals in the Indus River Basin have significantly reduced downstream flows and led to declining groundwater levels58. Moreover, the operation of large reservoirs such as the Hoover Dam on the Colorado River has drastically altered natural flow regimes and reduced seasonal flow variability59. While our streamflow projections are based on naturalized simulations from the VIC model, which intentionally omit direct human water management interventions such as dams, diversions, and irrigation, we nonetheless incorporated anthropogenic influences indirectly through spatial overlays with LULC and population density datasets. These overlays enabled a first-order assessment of how projected hydroclimatic extremes may intersect with human-modified landscapes and population hotspots, offering insight into potential exposure and impact zones under RCP 4.5 and RCP 8.5 scenarios. For instance, drought projections align strongly with cropland- and urban-dominated regions, while flooding risks intensify in forested and transitional areas experiencing urban growth. These patterns underscore the importance of interpreting hydrological extremes not in isolation, but within the broader socio-environmental context.Although our analysis reveals increasing occurrences of hydrological whiplash events across CONUS3,60, modified Mann-Kendall test results indicate no statistically significant trends in water year types or transitions for most HUC regions (Fig. S6). This apparent disconnect reflects limitations in both the methodology and the observational record. The Mann-Kendall test, while robust for detecting monotonic trends, may lack sensitivity to capture nonlinear changes or recent increases in extreme transitions, especially over relatively short time periods3,61. Moreover, the clustering of intense drought-to-flood or flood-to-drought events in recent years, such as those observed in California3,62, may signal emerging climate-driven variability not yet detectable as a long-term statistical trend. These findings highlight the importance of complementing traditional trend analysis with alternative approaches, such as change-point detection or extreme value theory63, and underscore the need for longer datasets to robustly assess evolving hydrological dynamics under a changing climate64. Moreover, projections of streamflow based on CMIP5 climate simulations are subject to uncertainty, stemming from biases in climate model outputs, hydrological model assumptions, and the complex interaction between atmospheric forcing and watershed response. Additionally, a key limitation of historical streamflow data obtained from USGS stations lies in the variability and potential inaccuracy. Although the USGS provides extensive hydrological records, the quality, continuity, and representativeness of these data can still vary across regions and time periods. To mitigate this issue, we retained only those daily observations carrying the USGS good quality flag, i.e., measurements that meet the agency’s highest accuracy standards and require no gap-filling or rating-curve adjustments, thereby maximizing data reliability while maintaining a consistent screening criterion nationwide. This spatial heterogeneity in data availability may influence our water year classifications and reduce confidence in some regional projections. Analysis of multiyear drought deficit uncovers that population in high-risk, low-resilience communities face disproportionately greater future water scarcity, including issues with safe, affordable drinking water, and are likely to experience climate-driven impacts earlier and more acutely65. Evolving climate conditions may alter historical risk levels, potentially increasing vulnerability in currently low-risk communities while allowing efforts to improve resilience in vulnerable areas. Integrating historical risk assessments with future projections provides a foundational benchmark, but dynamic approaches are needed to account for shifting community risks and resilience. Furthermore, interconnected water systems, such as the California State Water Project’s reliance on the Colorado River Aqueduct, illustrate how drought conditions in one region can impact distant communities66. These interdependencies highlight the critical need to consider water system magnitude and connectivity in assessing Local-scale drought risks.Key results show that although historical records reveal no significant trend in hydrological whiplashes, models project more extreme and fewer normal water years ahead6,13, signaling greater variability and new challenges for U.S. water management. Our study advances prior work67,68,69,70 by (1) combining a streamflow-based classification across all CONUS basins with an annual hydrological-whiplash metric; (2) applying uniform percentile thresholds to classify water-year types; (3) overlaying the resulting Hydrological Water Year Index with Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA) National Risk Index to locate socioeconomic and hazard-vulnerability hotspots; and (4) projecting future water-year distributions under RCP 4.5 and RCP 8.5. Integrating these methods highlights where projected extremes and social vulnerability coincide, pinpointing the communities most in need of targeted adaptation. The California Water Plan 2023 exemplifies how linking climate urgency, watershed resilience, and social equity can guide such efforts at scale65. Future work will extend this framework globally and incorporate CMIP6-based streamflow forecasts to refine adaptive strategies3,71.MethodsDataThis study utilized multiple data sources to investigate hydrological variations. Streamflow data were sourced from the USGS National Water Information System72, which offers comprehensive streamflow records across the U.S. Specifically, daily streamflow data spanning 1981 to 2023 were analyzed, providing a robust historical foundation for the study. The selection process focused on identifying stations with long-term, continuous records from key river basins in the CONUS. To ensure consistency and avoid uncertainties associated with data infilling, only stations with complete daily discharge records, i.e., no missing values throughout the entire study period, were retained, ensuring the analysis remains firmly grounded in observed data. The resulting hydrologic dataset therefore couples two sources that differ in the degree to which human water-management signals are represented: (i) historical USGS gauges with only good flags were chosen, which inevitably reflect anthropogenic influences such as dam operations, diversions, and groundwater pumping because nationwide regulation metadata are incomplete; and (ii) future projections from the VIC model, whose standard configuration yields fully naturalized runoff and streamflow driven solely by meteorological forcing and land-surface processes, without reservoir operations or consumptive withdrawals. This mixed-source strategy allows us to benchmark climate-driven changes against rich observational variability while ensuring that forward projections isolate the influence of climate forcing alone. This approach also minimizes the risk of introducing artificial trends or anomalies that could distort analyses of climate change impacts73,74,75.Future hydrological condition scenarios were developed using a combination of climate projections, outputs from hydrological models, and risk indices to assess the potential impacts of climate change on water resources and community resilience. Climate projection data were obtained from CMIP5, accessed through the Climate and Hydrology Projections portal. Specifically, the LOCA and BCSD hydrology projections were utilized2. These datasets provide statistically downscaled climate projections for regional hydrological assessments.LOCA downscales global‑climate outputs with a daily analog method at ~6 km (1/16°) resolution, retaining GCM‑projected changes, whereas BCSD employs monthly quantile mapping at ~12 km (1/8°) resolution to match historical variability. Both products provide daily precipitation and temperature for 2006–2099 and drive the VIC hydrologic model to produce runoff. We analyze an ensemble of 30 CMIP5 models under two emissions pathways RCP 4.5 (moderate) and RCP 8.5 (high). In the western U.S., VIC runoff was routed to generate naturalized streamflow, enabling calculation of streamflow indices and classification of future hydrologic conditions across basins. Because these simulations exclude regulations such as reservoirs and diversions, modeled flows may differ from USGS observations in heavily managed watersheds. To enhance the analysis, risk indices were incorporated to contextualize the hydrological projections. Specifically, the FEMA National Risk Index (NRI) was used to evaluate risks related to drought and other hazards76. The NRI provides a comprehensive assessment of community-level vulnerabilities by integrating expected annual losses (EAL), social vulnerabilities, and community resilience factors. In this study, these indices were used for spatial overlay and interpretation only, not for calibrating hydrological models. items.body: Sostenibilità Pensi di essere un genio? Prova a superare questa sfida impossibile che sta facendo impazzire il web    Roberto Arciola    Agosto 15, 2025     Le regole imprescindibili dell’ordine delle operazioni(www.greenstyle.it) Nel panorama delle sfide matematiche virali, un enigma apparentemente semplice continua a mettere in difficoltà migliaia di utenti.Questa espressione, che a prima vista sembra banale, nasconde insidie legate all’interpretazione errata delle regole fondamentali dell’aritmetica. La capacità di risolverla correttamente dipende dalla conoscenza rigorosa dell’ordine delle operazioni, un principio matematico spesso sottovalutato ma fondamentale per evitare errori comuni.In matematica, non si procede semplicemente da sinistra verso destra eseguendo le operazioni nell’ordine in cui appaiono. Esiste una gerarchia precisa e universalmente riconosciuta, nota con l’acronimo PEMDAS (Parentesi, Esponenti, Moltiplicazioni e Divisioni, Addizioni e Sottrazioni), che determina la priorità con cui svolgere le operazioni.La regola fondamentale è la seguente: prima si eseguono moltiplicazioni e divisioni, procedendo da sinistra verso destra, e solo successivamente addizioni e sottrazioni, anch’esse da sinistra verso destra. Questo ordine è fondamentale per garantire risultati univoci e corretti, evitando fraintendimenti che possono portare a errori grossolani.Un approfondimento da Wikipedia sull’ordine delle operazioni conferma che, in assenza di parentesi, si eseguono prima moltiplicazioni e divisioni, poi addizioni e sottrazioni, seguendo un preciso criterio temporale e gerarchico.Come risolvere correttamente l’espressione viraleIl calcolo da effettuare è:6 – 2 x 3 + 12 ÷ 2Procedendo con il corretto ordine delle operazioni:Prima la moltiplicazione: 2 x 3 = 6Poi la divisione: 12 ÷ 2 = 6A questo punto, l’espressione si riduce a:6 – 6 + 6Si procede da sinistra verso destra con addizioni e sottrazioni:6 – 6 = 00 + 6 = 6Il risultato finale corretto è quindi 6, non 9 come spesso viene erroneamente indicato da chi ignora o dimentica l’ordine delle operazioni. Il fascino e l’importanza delle sfide logiche matematiche(www.greenstyle.it)Questa sfida virale non è solo un gioco di calcolo: rappresenta un esempio concreto di come le regole matematiche siano essenziali per risolvere problemi e stimolare il ragionamento critico. Oltre a divertirsi, infatti, esercitarsi su quiz di questo tipo permette di:Migliorare la concentrazione mentalePotenziare il pensiero logico e criticoEvitare errori nelle situazioni reali in cui è richiesta accuratezza nei calcoliÈ proprio questa combinazione di divertimento e utilità che rende i test matematici virali così popolari sui social media.Un cenno va poi fatto al numero 6, risultato dell’espressione: un numero con molteplici proprietà matematiche e naturali. È il primo numero perfetto, perché la somma dei suoi divisori (1 + 2 + 3) è uguale a sé stesso. Inoltre, le sue forme esagonali sono presenti in natura, ad esempio nei favi delle api, segno della sua armonia e simmetria.Attenzione ai tranelli e all’importanza della precisioneLe sfide matematiche virali come questa dimostrano quanto sia facile cadere in tranelli se non si conoscono o non si applicano correttamente le regole. Spesso, la superficialità nel calcolo porta a risultati sbagliati e a una confusione che può essere evitata solo con una solida conoscenza delle basi dell’aritmetica.Parallelamente, è importante sottolineare che non tutte le challenge virali sono innocue o educative. Recentemente, come evidenziato da campagne di sensibilizzazione della Fondazione Artemisia, alcune sfide social possono essere pericolose, soprattutto per i più giovani, che spesso sottovalutano i rischi. Questo rende ancora più rilevante promuovere contenuti che stimolino la mente in modo costruttivo e sicuro.Seguire e partecipare a queste sfide matematiche non solo intrattiene, ma aiuta a mantenere il cervello allenato, sviluppando capacità che risultano preziose anche al di fuori del contesto ludico. items.body:
Download PDF

Article
    
        
            Open access

Published: 15 August 2025

Local hourly trends in near-surface and land surface temperatures
                    Sarah Safieddine1, Cathy Clerbaux1, Joaquín Muñoz-Sabater2 & …Jean-Noël Thépaut2 Show authors

Scientific Reports

volume 15, Article number: 29915 (2025)
            Cite this article

Subjects
        
            Climate changeClimate sciences

AbstractEssential Climate Variables, such as near-surface (T2m) and land surface temperatures (LST), are typically reported in Coordinated Universal Time (UTC) for global consistency. However, their diurnal variability leads to temperature trends that differ by the local hour, a factor not analyzed on the global nor regional scale. Using ECMWF ERA5-Land reanalysis data (1981–2022), we assess temperature trends by local hour and month. Our results show that the trends can change significantly during the day. LST and T2m warming or cooling trends peak in the afternoon, while showing large spatial variability across both hemispheres. Using MODIS observations, we show how the nominal Equator crossing times of TERRA and AQUA influence LST trends. These findings highlight the necessity of accounting for local time in climate assessments to improve adaptation strategies.
